awd_titl_txt: IGE: STEM Graduate training in Data Science: solution-oriented, student-led, team-based, computationally-enriched (SOLSTICE) training
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been a rapid increase in both the amount and type of data collected in many fields of science, technology and engineering; this requires new approaches to train graduate students to meet these needs.  The new data revolution calls for a new data-savvy workforce capable of using data effectively to answer important scientific and practical questions and to communicate the results to a broad audience. These data scientists should have strong technical and leadership skills and the ability to work in teams comprising different and complementary expertise. To meet this training need, the National Science Foundation Innovations of Graduate Education (IGE) award to Tufts University will test an innovative approach to project-based learning, teaching graduate students in data-intensive fields using real datasets to solve real-world problems. This solution-oriented, student-led, team-based, computationally-enriched (SOLSTICE) training environment will offer multidisciplinary team role-play and experience in data analytics and scientific communication. This project will evaluate the effectiveness of the SOLSTICE approach in providing an adaptable method for instructors in a range of fields that use large datasets at diverse institution types. As the SOLSTICE approach is refined, it will pave the way for students to enter the workforce with strong technical skills in data analytics and be effective members of research teams. 

The project will answer two overarching research questions: (1) To what extent does the SOLSTICE approach provide opportunities for students to achieve 21st-century data intensive knowledge, skills, and attitudes? and (2) Are there variations in students' achievement over time, across different courses that use the SOLSTICE approach, and across different STEM disciplines? The approach consists of three components: (1) 3D Role Play, in which each student plays the role of Team Lead, Collaborator, and Reviewer in three different interdisciplinary teams aiming to develop, execute and communicate a research project based on authentic secondary data analyses; (2) Feedback on Feedback, which provides students with experience in giving and receiving effective critiques to their peers to strengthen inter-team communication; and (3) Data Analysis Roadmap, which offers knowledge-building guides and examples of key elements for efficient data analysis plans and other documents needed for effective communication of results. The approach will be tested and evaluated in six data-intensive courses in the Friedman School of Nutrition and in the School of Engineering, with approximately 270 participants monitored before, during, and for at least six months after participation in a SOLSTICE-based course. Educational resources will be developed based on successful components to guide replications of the training process, to train faculty in the SOLSTICE approach, and to disseminate it to other STEM fields. 

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Innovative approaches for STEM education that address the rapidly changing demands of data-intensive fields are critical to prepare graduate students for the modern workforce. We conducted an NSF-funded study aimed at implementing, evaluating, and disseminating a transformative learning approach to offer students SOLution-oriented, STudent-Initiated, Computationally-Enriched (SOLSTICE) training. The SOLSTICE approach emphasizes the incorporation of three components in the course curricula: 3D Role Play to facilitate team-based problem solving; Feedback-on-Feedback to enhance collaborative work; and an Analytic Roadmap to support the navigation and management of a semester-long project.

In SOLSTICE-based courses, each student was designated the Principal Investigator (PI) of their own research project, a collaborating PI (Co-PI) of one partner's project, and a Reviewer of a second partner's project. Thus, mimicking team-based research environments, 3D Role allowed each student to lead their own project, collaborate with a peer's project, and evaluate or review another peer's research. Each week, groups have designated instruction time for in-class discussions, peer feedback, and feedback on the quality and focus area of each other's feedback (e.g., Feedback-on-Feedback). To facilitate collaboration, course instructors developed online discussion forums where homework assignment responses were posted and commented on prior to in-class discussion. For courses rich in the instruction of visualization software, student websites were created using WordPress to create a research portfolio for storing images. These websites aimed to communicate research to diverse audiences and were designed to demonstrate the effects before and after addressing peer feedback comments and recommendations. Peer feedback and Feedback-on-Feedback was also integrated into midterm and end-of-term project rubrics to encourage collaborative discussion of research hypotheses, statistical methodology, and anticipated research challenges. Finally, to hone project and time management skills, we required students to complete data management and analysis plans (DMAPs) to serve as a roadmap for midterm and final project submissions. These plans were completed incrementally throughout the semester; each weekly assignment incorporated questions from the final DMAP that, when combined, ensured its completion by the conclusion of the semester. This scaffolded incremental approach also allowed for students to iteratively reflect on and revise research project components, including data quality inspections, study aims, research hypotheses, analytical methods, visuals, and results tables/figures, throughout the semester.   

As part of the human subjects IRB approval process (approved in January 2020), we received written approval to enroll courses across 6 schools of Tufts University. These schools reside on 3 campuses and offer a wide range of data-intensive courses in engineering, social, medical, and veterinary sciences. For each participating school, we reviewed all available courses prior to each academic semester to identify those suitable for participation. Of all available courses, we created an inventory of 30 courses whose syllabi met the following criteria: a) most enrolled students had graduate level standing; and b) course objectives emphasized skills to form research hypotheses and require students to examine, analyze, and/or visualize data (biostatistics, statistics, geographic information systems, remote sensing, data visualization, statistical programming, epidemiology, informatics, etc.); and c) courses with midterm and end of term projects or project-based learning opportunities prioritized student research projects. Instructors for these courses were invited to participate in the study and offered clarifications on the study design, consent process, and pre/post-assessment surveys via remote information sessions.

Over the 3-year study, we collected pre/post assessments from 249 consented students enrolled in 26 data-intensive courses to explore how well the proposed approach provided opportunities to achieve the desired knowledge, skills, and attitudes. The 95-question surveys were constructed to reflect the proficiency in introductory, intermediate, and advanced tasks typically performed in data-intensive courses. The questions were asked on a student's years of active experience with specific software packages and programming languages and their preferred software to perform data management and analysis tasks; students' experiences providing and receiving peer feedback and critical evaluation; familiarity with common tools to complete data-oriented tasks, and students' opinions regarding the importance of those tools. Students' responces were collected using an electronic survey hosted on the Qualtrics platform at the beginning (entry survey) and end (exit survey) of each academic semester. We created knowledge, skills, and attitudes scores based on questions ranked in accordance with typical requirements for introductory, intermediate, and advanced courses for students studying public health, nutrition, and biological/environmental sciences.

We compared the change in knowledge, skills, and attitudes scores among 158 students whose courses fully or partially implemented the SOLSTICE approach (treatment group) and compared this group to the 91 students whose courses did not implement the SOLSTICE approach (control group) using linear regression models adjusted for baseline score levels and key demographic factors. While significant improvements were observed in all participating courses, students exposed to the SOLSTICE training approach demonstrated significantly higher advanced knowledge as compared to controls. Furthermore, students taking SOLSTICE-based courses were often engaged in research activities, participated in scientific conferences, and publishing their work in peer-reviewed journals.
